nodes.text: IT projects are riskier than commonly believed because a disproportionate number produce extreme overages (Black Swans) that can sink companies and careers, so CEOs must explicitly manage this fat-tail risk
The true pitfall of IT change initiatives is a fat tail of very large cost and schedule overruns rather than a high average overrun
We examined a global sample of 1,471 IT change projects comparing budgets and estimated benefits with actual costs and results across ERP, management information, and CRM systems
Average cost overrun across the sample was 27% and average project cost was $167 million (largest $33 billion)
One in six projects was a Black Swan with average cost overrun of 200% and schedule overrun of almost 70%
By focusing on averages instead of outliers, managers and consultants have been missing the real, damaging risk posed by the unusually large proportion of Black Swans
Levi Strauss SAP migration budgeted under $5 million led to operational failures and a $192.5 million charge and the CIO's resignation
Kmart undertook large IT modernization and supply chain projects that went off the rails and contributed to its 2002 bankruptcy and large store closures
Toll Collect integration failures left the German government with an estimated more than $10 billion in lost revenue
Mismanaged IT projects have caused top managers to lose jobs, ruined companies, and in aggregate can harm regional economies and national revenue

We recommend a stress test: can the company absorb its biggest tech project going over budget by 400% with only 25 to 50 percent of benefits realized, and can it absorb 15 percent of medium projects exceeding costs by 200 percent
To avoid IT Black Swans managers should break big projects into limited-size modules, plan contingencies for unavoidable risks, resist scope creep, and use the best forecasting techniques
Reference class forecasting, based on Kahneman and Tversky, uses outcomes from similar projects to improve prediction and is mandatory for big public projects in the UK and Denmark

A success case: Emirates NBD completed a doubled-size core banking project with only 7% schedule slip and 18% cost overrun by sticking to schedule, resisting scope changes, modularizing work, assembling the right team, preventing turnover, framing it as a business initiative, and focusing on readiness to go live

An underlying cause is that software has become integral to products and processes while engineers and managers often lack sufficient understanding to implement complex technology components, leading to integration and configuration failures (examples: Airbus A380 wiring/configuration issues, Hong Kong airport systems)
Conclusion: Top managers and CEOs must recognize fat-tail IT risk, perform stress tests, and adopt modularization and forecasting practices to reduce the chance of catastrophic project failures
